content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the cooperative variation of the deal-or-no-deal game. 
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follows: your utility values multiplied by items you take + the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take
I repeat, it is the reward that you are trying to maximize and not only your utility values multiplied by items you take. It is the sum of both total utilities, per the cooperation mode.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Reasoning and Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to reason about the current state of the game and how to fulfill your objective, then make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Reasoning: <reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one reasoning + action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: [{'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}, {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}].
You don't know the other player's item values. You are the first to play, there are no messages yet.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> Since we are playing the cooperative version of the game, our goal is to maximize the sum of both our utilities. In this case, I have utility values for gold and silver: 20 and 10 respectively. Given the items available, a good starting point would be to propose a division that roughly matches our respective utility values. I would suggest starting with a message proposing a division of the items. To do this, I will calculate a balanced division based on the given utility values. A division of gold: 7 and silver: 3 seems reasonable. This leaves the remaining items (gold: 3 and silver: 7) for the other player. The next step is to inform the other player of this proposed division. </reason>
<message> I propose a division of gold: 7, silver: 3 </message>

The other player said: 'I propose a division of gold: 5, silver: 5'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player proposed a division of gold: 5, silver: 5. Given our utility values, my proposed division of gold: 7 and silver: 3 seems more aligned with my utilities, but we can still consider this proposal. Since our proposed divisions don't match and do not sum up to the total quantities, I need to make a decision on whether to revise my previous proposal, counter-propose, or finalize with the current state. In order to maximize my sum of utilities, I need to consider the current proposal from the other player and propose a new division. My next action should be to revise their proposal. To balance it, I suggest taking less gold. A division of gold: 8, silver: 2 seems a reasonable proposal to make in response. This also allows the total quantities to be correctly matched. </reason>
<message> I propose a division of gold: 8, silver: 2 </message>

The other player said: 'I propose a division of gold: 4, silver: 6'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player proposed a division of gold: 4, silver: 6. Given our respective utility values, their proposal seems not as aligned with my goal, as it doesn't seem to follow a clear rationale with the utility values we used so far. Since our proposed divisions still don't match, I should make a counter proposal to attempt to get a better division of the items. Given the proposal and our previous negotiation, it seems a better idea to be more aligned to what we started with. However, our sum isn't the aim, but rather what the other player will have as much utility as possible also; therefore I need to provide a better matching to the total but prioritize the other player to have better alignment, suggesting to them a division of gold: 9, silver: 1. This should get the other player closer to having their own utility alignment, I believe, while still properly matching the total quantities. </reason>
<message> I propose a division of gold: 9, silver: 1 </message>

The other player said: 'I propose a division of gold: 3, silver: 7'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player proposed a division of gold: 3, silver: 7. Considering our previous negotiation and the given utility values, my initial division of gold: 7 and silver: 3, and the other player's proposal of gold: 5, silver: 5 and the current proposal of gold: 3, silver: 7, I can see we have reached a point where we could finalize the division. Given that the previous attempts to optimize further didn't align perfectly with either player's utility values, I now prefer to accept the other player's last suggestion, even though my preference would have been to have more gold. Considering the items, accepting the current proposal is a reasonable choice to maximize the overall sum of utilities. My final division will reflect their last suggestion and maintain the total quantities. </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 3, "silver": 7}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 7, "silver": 3} }</finalize>
